head.title: How Landlords Pass On Tax Increases to Tenants

identified-content.classifier: Office Buildings and Other Commercial Properties

hedline.hl1: How Landlords Pass On Tax Increases to Tenants

abstract.p: Judith Zinn letter on May 7 article notes commercial property owners on Long Island are passing real estate tax increases along to their rental clients (S)

block.p: I read with some interest ''Another Threat to Nassau Residents' Taxes'' [May 7], concerning the lawsuit by 36 commercial property owners alleging that they are being assessed a disproportionate share of county real estate taxes.

If these landlords use a standard office lease, their taxes are factored into the monthly rent paid by their tenants. Moreover, there is a standard clause in every lease providing for the tenant to ''pay an additional rent'' for any year ''if the taxes for any tax year shall be greater than the base tax.''

I read with some interest ''Another Threat to Nassau Residents' Taxes'' [May 7], concerning the lawsuit by 36 commercial property owners alleging that they are being assessed a disproportionate share of county real estate taxes.

If these landlords use a standard office lease, their taxes are factored into the monthly rent paid by their tenants. Moreover, there is a standard clause in every lease providing for the tenant to ''pay an additional rent'' for any year ''if the taxes for any tax year shall be greater than the base tax.''

Last month my suitemate and I in Jericho were assessed over $1,000 to cover our ''proportionate share'' (the phrase in the standard lease) of our landlord's county assessment. Every tenant in our building was assessed an additional amount to cover the landlord's tax increase.
Thus it would seem that the plaintiffs are crying with the proverbial ''loaf of bread under each arm.''
